introduction.p: Tracking a motion is the most basic way of representing motion. If you have taken a road trip or train journey, you are already familiar with this idea. Say, you mark the time you arrived at various points on a map from a road trip from Boston to San Framcisco as in . This would be your motion diagram.

figure.caption: A trip from Boston to San Francisco with each day marked is an example of a motion diagram. Credits: https://maps.google.com.

introduction.p: If you were moving on a straight path, you could view the motion occuring on one of the Cartesian axes, say the x axis. Your markings would give your x coordinates at various times, for which we would use letter t . This process yields x(t) , i.e., x coordinate as a function of t , making your markings amenable to further mathematical analysis.

Often we mark position at regular times so that motion diagram immediately tells us qualitative aspects of the motion, such as where an object is moving steadily, where speeding up, and where slowing down, as shown below.
shows two ways of tracking a car moving on a straight road - (a) a motion diagram and (b) a x versus t plot.

figure.caption: Two ways to show motion. (a) A motion diagram shows position at regular intervals of time - you might think of the dots marked every second. (b) A x versus t plot. The object is slowing between A and B, speeding up between C and D, and is steady between B and C.

introduction.p: From the motion diagram in , you can immediately sense that the car is slowing between A and B, moves at a steady pace between B and C, and speeding up betwen C and D.

In x versus t plot in , we can also connect the points and obtain a continuous function x(t) from the plot. Function x(t) can be used to define rate of motion, such as velocity, and other aspects of motion analytically.

exercise.title: A Boy Running On a Straight Track Uniformly

statement.p: shows a boy running on a straight track. The position of the boy is marked every 2 seconds. The line below the sketch shows the scale of length in the drawing.
(a) Draw x versus t representation on the motion diagram.
(b) Is the motion steady, slowing down, or speeding up? How can you tell?

hint.p: Use the scale to figure out distances from where the boy is at point marked 1.

answer.p: (a) See solution (b) Steady since covering same distance in same amount of time.

exercise.title: From x Versus t Plot to Motion Diagram

statement.p: shows a plot of x versus t . Draw a motion diagram that will result in this plot. Show space scales and indicate value of time on your diagram.

hint.p: Mark points on the ordinate at equal-time intervals.

solution.p: First we mark points on the ordinate axis at equal-time intervals. We choose to mark points separated by 10\text{ s} intervals. These points are shown as dots in x vs t plot in . Then we draw points on the x axis only to get the motion diagram, where we now mark each point with 1, 2, 3, ..., which stand for the instants, with 2 standing for 10 sec, 3 for 20 sec, etc.
